title: 108_hr898
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The Act of June 7, 1956 preamble is amended by recognizing the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes and a distinct Indian community since contact with settlers. North Carolina has recognized the Lumbee Indians as an Indian tribe since 1885. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina, descendants of coastal tribes like the Cheraw, have been recognized as an Indian tribe by the State of North Carolina since 1885 and by the US Congress in 1956. However, they have been denied federal benefits and privileges despite their federally recognized status. The Congress acknowledges the Lumbee Indians as a federally recognized tribe in 1956 but withheld benefits. They should now receive full federal recognition and associated privileges. The Lumbee Indians are acknowledged as a federally recognized tribe in 1956 but were denied benefits. They should now receive full federal recognition and associated privileges. SEC. 3. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by extending federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members in Robeson and adjoining counties. Laws and regulations of general application to Indians and Indian tribes will apply to the Lumbee Tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are granted federal recognition, allowing them to access services and benefits provided to federally recognized tribes. Other groups of Indians in the area can petition for tribal acknowledgement. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits as a federally recognized tribe. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior will verify a tribal roll for further development of services in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, residing in specific counties, is considered near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior will verify a tribal roll for further development of services in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, residing near an Indian reservation, will have their tribal roll verified by the Secretary of the Interior to determine needs and budget for eligible services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will also provide a written statement of needs and budget to Congress. The tribal roll will define the service population for the delivery of Federal services, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. The tribal roll, verified by the Secretary of the Interior, will define the service population for the delivery of Federal services. The verification process will confirm compliance with membership criteria set out in the tribe's constitution adopted on November 11, 2000. The Secretary's verification will be completed within 1 year of the enactment of this section. Sec. 4. Fee lands the tribe wants to convey to the US for trust shall be treated as 'on-reservation' trust acquisitions if located in Robeson County, North Carolina. Sec. 5. North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses committed within the area. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina can convey fee lands to the US for trust acquisitions in Robeson County. North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the tribe or held in trust by the United States. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to accept these trust acquisitions. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina can transfer jurisdiction of lands to the United States, with the Secretary of the Interior authorized to accept these transfers. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina can transfer jurisdiction of lands to the United States, with the Secretary of the Interior authorized to accept these transfers. The transfer may not take effect until 2 years after the agreement, and funding is authorized to carry out this Act.
